CNX_Chem_03_03_espresso.captionEn: Sugar is one of many components in the complex mixture known as coffee. The amount of sugar in a given amount of coffee is an important determinant of the beverage’s sweetness. (credit: Jane Whitney)
CNX_Chem_03_03_espresso.altText: A picture is shown of sugar being poured from a spoon into a cup.

CNX_Chem_03_04_vinegar.captionEn: Distilled white vinegar is a solution of acetic acid in water.
CNX_Chem_03_04_vinegar.altText: A label on a container is shown. The label has a picture of a salad with the words “Distilled White Vinegar,” and, “Reduced with water to 5% acidity,” written above it.

CNX_Chem_03_04_dilution.captionEn: Both solutions contain the same mass of copper nitrate. The solution on the right is more dilute because the copper nitrate is dissolved in more solvent. (credit: Mark Ott)
CNX_Chem_03_04_dilution.altText: This figure shows two graduated cylinders side-by-side. The first has about half as much blue liquid as the second. The blue liquid is darker in the first cylinder than in the second.
